recipes.label: Event: On the thin ice
recipes.startdescription: The Vicar finds the Prior in their room. They suggest writing a letter to the Pilgrim, who is the Lord of the land within the Bishop’s parish. The Pilgrim is in Constantinople. They may or may not have heard the news from their own servants. Regardless, the Vicar believes that they should inform the Pilgrim.

recipes.label: Event: On the thin ice
recipes.startdescription: However, the Prior doesn’t know if the Pilgrim and the Bishop are in good terms or not. They are hesitant to meddle with their business. Instead, they could wait until the Bishop wakes up.
recipes.description: The Vicar disagrees, saying that they are not even sure if the Bishop would live. They certainly do not want the blame to fall on them in case the Bishop dies. The Prior concedes on that note.

recipes.label: Fort Forest: Hunter
recipes.startdescription: The weather is nice today. The Knight decides to go hunting with the Soldier, so they can get some spoils for trade, and also practice archery.
recipes.description: They only got a few rabbits and birds, but they had fun riding in the wind and competing against each other.

recipes.label: Fort Forest: Hunt
recipes.startdescription: The Knight decides to go hunting today in hope of getting some good spoils to trade. After a few hours roaming and tracking in the forest, they finally spot a horde of deer.
recipes.description: They sneak close and take an aim. The arrow pierces right into the deer's neck. The Knight lets out a laugh. Its pelt would be a good trade, and its meat shall make a hearty meal for tonight.

recipes.label: Fort Trading Post: Trade
recipes.startdescription: The Knight would like to trade the pelt for a bag of flour, so they can give it as a gift to recruit a new soldier, along with a few eggs for themselves.
recipes.description: The merchant sees the Knight is well-dressed and therefore pitches to them how good their flour is, emphasizing it being worthy to exchange with one good pelt, if not with more. The Knight, not in the mood to argue, agrees to take only a bag of flour.

recipes.label: Fort Trading Post: Trade
recipes.startdescription: The Knight noticed that the young person’s family has neither table nor chairs for dinning and decides to trade a set for them. The merchant is more reluctant this time and being sarcastic of their stinginess.
recipes.description: The Knight’s temper arises, calling the merchant a profiteer. They start to argue with each other. Eventually, the Knight irritatedly claims that they would exchange the pelt for coins and buy a set of tables and chairs elsewhere. Only then, the merchant yields and sells the set to the Knight.

recipes.label: Fort Trading Post: Trade
recipes.startdescription: The Knight walks into the trading post with pelt in hand, and is warmly welcomed by the merchant there. The Knight beams back. (1 pelt = 1 prosper point)
recipes.description: "Your pelt is alway well-liked. Even our business got better!" says the merchant. "My pleasure." replies the Knight with a nod.

recipes.label: Event: Recruit the rookie. Part 1
recipes.startdescription: The Scribe once suggested the Knight to recruit someone who lives in the forest. The young person is obsessed with archery and determined to join an army, but their family is unwilling to part with them. A gift such as a bag of flour may help persuade the family.
recipes.description: The Knight is surprised to find that they have met the young person before, and was impressed with their archery. The young person is delighted to join them, but their family still hesitates. The Knight didn’t push the family, and they will revisit again in a few weeks.

recipes.label: Event: Recruit the rookie. Part 2
recipes.startdescription: The Knight pays another visit, bringing a set of table and chairs along with them. The young one’s family is surprised and grateful of the gift. They are moved by the Knight’s sincerity.
recipes.description: The young one’s family agrees and the rookie excitedly joins the Knight. They don’t have much to pack. The Knight feels guilty for having no money to pay them, but promises to send the family food from time to time.

recipes.label: Retrieve the letter to the Pilgrim
recipes.startdescription: The Monk looks reluctant but agrees to write a letter. When they realize the letter is to the Pilgrim on the matter of the Bishop’s injuries, they seem more eager to write it. The Vicar knows that the Monk used to serve under the same parish as the Pilgrim, and so they trust the Monk in this matter.

recipes.label: Read the letter?
recipes.startdescription: Later in the afternoon, the Vicar finds the Monk in the library with the letter completed. As they retrieve the letter, the Monk asks the Vicar about the Bishop's injuries. Slightly surprised, the Vicar replies that the Bishop is still unconscious. Although the injuries have stopped worsening, it’s difficult to say if the Bishop will survive.

recipes.label: Read the letter?
recipes.startdescription: The Monk seems to be upset. Out of curiousity, the Vicar asks if the Bishop and the Pilgrim have been on good terms. The Monk says yes as far as they know. The Vicar thanks the Monk and takes the letter.

recipes.label: Read the letter?
recipes.startdescription: It is clear that the Monk is keeping in touch with either the Pilgrim or the Bishop. They might know more about what happened than anyone else here. That makes the Vicar feels concerned. Maybe they should read the letter just be sure.

recipes.label: The Vicar reads the letter
recipes.startdescription: The Vicar goes back to their own place and reads the letter. In the letter, the Monk details the Bishop’s current state of health, indicating that the church is doing their best to treat the injuries, but also preparing for the worst.
recipes.description: While the letter seems flawless, it has a tone of deep concern and urgency, which the Vicar has no intention of conveying. Sealing the letter and sending it out, the Vicar wonders if the Monk knows who or what might have led to the Bishop's injuries...

recipes.label: The Vicar chooses not to read the letter
recipes.startdescription: The Vicar trusts the Monk. They are writing on behalf of the church, not themselves. They would not include additional information even if they know more details. Doing so could make both the Vicar and the Pilgrim suspicious.
recipes.description: The Vicar seals the letter and sends it out without reading, but they wonder if they should keep an eye on the Monk’s recent personal correspondence...
